children.subject: Posting as a follow-up since I don't personally have experience with this, but Scientific Computing is listed as a research area on the EECS website. The webpage lists a few courses: CS267, CS274, and EE219A. Signal processing (EE123) also seems like it might be useful.

history.content:
(take all of my advice with a grain of salt)

CS186, CS164, CS267 are all highly relevant, but I would say they're a little bit lower level than you need to get started. The fastest way is probably by taking a look at the big open source projects in this area, namely Jupyter/IPython (http://jupyter.org/) and Pandas/Scipy/Numpy. 


In terms of path, one ideal model that comes into mind is UW's CS department (specifically their database group), which has tight collaborations with the sciences.

I think (might be wrong) that the connection of sciences <=> core CS is a bit weaker here at Berkeley, but the equivalent organization here is the Institute of Data Science (https://bids.berkeley.edu/research). They develop applications/tools for scientists centered around data management/processing (like Jupyter). More on the CS side, the RISE Lab builds general purpose big data processing tools (Spark, Ray, etc), which may be of interest to scientists/researchers. RISE doesn't brand itself/strongly associate with scientific tooling, but interestingly enough, RISE also has some graduate students with projects focusing on large scale genomics data processing.

In a broader sense, spending all of this effort to help out the above projects might actually not be as impactful as one would hope because a lot of scientists are married to their current tech stack (MPI, R, Stata, etc) and are unwilling to move to other ("better") tools. If you want to be really impactful, I would spend some time understanding what are the needs and pain points of current scientific processing, understanding why people are refusing to move off of Stata/R/MPI, and choosing a lab where there are projects are tackling these pain points. I would also consider just cold emailing some of the BIDS people to ask them about their research; I'm sure they'd be glad to talk to you if you ask nicely!

I want to look into a career in producing tools for scientists/researchers in other fields. A lot of the cool work in this field is in databases, languages (stuff like Julia), parallel/high performance computing, as well as traditional software for specific use cases.

What CS classes are applicable here? So far I have been very theory oriented (189, 170, 126, 127). I know 186 is applicable for databases, 164 for languages, but what about parallel computing and such? Anyone else look into this path before and have recommended courses to look into?

Aside from courses, any specific things to do in this area?

Thanks.
history.subject: Suggested things to do for interest in scientific computing?
